Deputy Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, today the regional municipality of Sudbury is being recognized by the United Nations and has been presented with the 1992 United Nations Local Government Honours Award at the earth summit in Rio de Janeiro for its work in land reclamation.
Sudbury is green and getting greener every day. Lands once barren and devastated are covered in grass and trees; all this due to the co-operation of all within the community as well as with the help of all levels of government.
First, Sudbury's efforts were recognized in Ontario and in 1990 Sudbury was awarded the Lieutenant-Governor's Conservation Award. Again in 1990 Sudbury received the Government of Canada Environmental Achievement Award.
Earlier this year Sudbury's work was recognized by the United States and received the Chevron Conservation Award, and now the world recognizes Sudbury's achievements. Sudbury has become a world leader in vegetation enhancement.
All Canadians can be justly proud of these outstanding achievements and of the international recognition. Congratulations Sudbury.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, shelters for battered women give out only their phone numbers and not their addresses because it would endanger the lives of women and children. Abusive men
are most likely to kill their partners when the women attempt to leave them.
Shelter workers and others who have helped battered women have also been threatened, beaten and killed. A Liberal member of Parliament, without consulting the organizations involved, published the addresses of all the shelters for battered women in his riding. Women's organizations wish to hold the member for Broadview- Greenwood accountable.
Women's organizations who help battered women are the experts on this issue. I urge all members of Parliament to consult with these women's organizations in their ridings before sending out any material dealing with violence against women. This recent action which puts abused women and children at further risk could have been completely avoided.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, a constituent of mine has brought to my attention the following matter of great importance.
Future eastern Canadian summers without the monarch butterfly are a certainty because of the logging of the few Mexican mountain top sanctuaries where these insects stay over winter. Saving the Mexican winter range for the monarch is of great importance.
Currently our Minister for International Trade is on a mission to Mexico to discuss environmental technology and has said that the President of Mexico has placed a very high priority on improving Mexico's environmental protection and control capabilities.
Sustainable growth should blend a genuine commitment to the environment with a consistent focus on quality. It will take effort by all of us to make this a reality.
Today, as the earth summit convenes in Rio de Janiero, I encourage all members of Parliament to support and encourage efforts to preserve the world's forests, wildlife and beautiful species for the enjoyment of North Americans now and in the future.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this year alone there will be almost 16,000 newly diagnosed cases of breast cancer and 5,200 women will die of this disease in Canada.
We cannot understate this problem. Breast cancer today is a crisis of epidemic proportions, and yet it is still being largely ignored.
According to the Laboratory Centre for Disease Control, breast cancer research is severely underfunded. In fact the Medical Research Council only spends $1 million a year out of its $182 million research budget to combat a disease that affects one in nine women. The National Health and Research Development Program spends a "whopping" $40,000.
I suspect these figures are correct because when I contacted health and welfare for confirmation it would not release any figures to me despite the fact that it had them. The reason for this was that they had to be cleared by the director of the department.
Could it be that the government was too embarrassed to tell us the truth? It is time that we recognized the scope of this problem and allot the necessary funds to it.
When the government can find $20 million for ad campaigns, I am certain it can do more to combat breast cancer. If we are really interested in equality for women then the logical starting point would be to ensure basic equality for the health and welfare of all our citizens.

speakerposition: Bloc Québécois House Leader
subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, yesterday the Law Reform Commission of Canada released paper entitled Procurement and Transfer of Human Tissues and Organs. The document contained several important recommendations regarding this vital medical practice, among them that organs and tissues for use in transplant or research should be obtained through donation rather than purchase.
I believe this recommendation is excellent and I call on this government to act upon it. Besides the moral argument for respect for the living and the dead, there are very sound practical reasons for this recommendation.
Canada has an impressive track record for blood donations. We do not pay for blood, and thus generally those who donate do so for purely altruistic reasons. The United States health care community is forced to pay for certain blood products. This has created a market where people who are knowingly unqualified donors can sell bad blood for the sake of personal gain or compromising their own health for money.
The same holds true for organs and tissue. People should be donating these for the purpose of preserving and protecting life. I support the commission's call for making the purchase or sale of human bodies, organs and other non-regenerative tissue a Criminal Code offence.

Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Youth); Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, we can never stress enough the importance of buying Canadian. That is why I want to emphasize the importance of encouraging Canadians to shop at home and buy our products.
The economy is getting back on track slowly but surely. Therefore, we must be vigilant in order to keep this recovery going. Yet, certain aspects of the economy are not protected enough, which could jeopardize this upturn.
An example of this is that lots of people want to work in Canada where salaries and wages are the highest in North America. However, a number of those people spend the money they earn in Canada in the United States, and that will have negative effects on our economy. No country in the world can resist such a regime very long.
Therefore, I urge everyone from all regions, particularly the people of my riding, to deal with their own people with trust. Our economic future depends closely on our capacity to save what we have.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Organization of Economic Co-Operation and Development recently published its annual farm subsidy figures and again the figures are misleading.
The OECD claims Canadian farmers receive subsidies totalling $8.8 million. It has been calculated that this figure is five times the actual support level. The OECD assumes that any amount above the world price for any product is a subsidy.
In the world market, the so-called world price of most commodities is far below the cost of production because
of subsdized surpluses. The Canadian domestic price is higher than the world price because the world price is rock bottom.
If we use the OECD's rationale, we could say that a Canadian factory worker is being subsidized by the Canadian taxpayer because his or her wage is higher than the world salary rate. The OECD's definition of world price misrepresents the real picture.
Canadians receive the best value in the world for food in terms of price, quality, wholesomeness and safety.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, for many months, Canadians and Quebecers have been discussing the Senate reform. In today's La Presse, an article written by Maurice Girard is entitled: "Benoit Bouchard: Should the Senate be abolished?" And further: "Having spoken very clearly today, Mr. Bourassa can take the lead in favor of a more equal Senate". It is quite possible. I ask again: Should we not abolish the Senate outright? It would be a lot simpler.
Mr. Speaker, I am in favor of a "triple E" Senate. First, Elect the senators as federal members of Parliament, since several of them are competent; second, Eliminate it; third, End it, for the good of taxpayers.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, a Nigerian refugee claimant facing deportation has sought sanctuary in the Vancouver Collingwood United Church after he received a deportation order in early May.
Steven Ogunwuyi was implicated in the April 1990 failed coup in Nigeria, and Amnesty International and the Vancouver Refugee Council oppose his removal because of widespread evidence which indicates that executions, torture and inhumane treatment have been meted out to all who have been accused of attempting to overthrow dictator Ibrahim Babangida.


Moves to provide sanctuary to refugees facing life threatening deportation orders can only increase as the Conservative government further restricts the asylum it provides to people fleeing persecution.
I call on the government to establish a moratorium on deportations to Nigeria until the political situation has been clarified and the outcome of the upcoming elections determined.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, last week I was in Cyprus. I would like to take the time I am allowed to say to you, and through you to all Canadians, how proud I felt while spending an evening with the Canadian soldiers who are acting as peacekeepers and peacemakers in that region.
I attended the presentation of the United Nations medals to the 3rd Battalion of the Royal 22nd Regiment. I met Lieutenant-Colonel Gagnon and I spoke with French Canadians from the Saguenay, Lac Saint-Jean, the Eastern Townships, Lac Megantic, Laval and other regions. I listened to O Canada being sung in French by all those military, I saw our flag fluttering quite high and well in view, I heard the band of the 1st Battalion of The Worcestershire and Sherwood Forester Regiment play a song I had learned as a child when my mother sang it for me: Vive la Canadienne.
Mr. Speaker, I was proud to be a Canadian and I cried with emotion. I thank the commander of the force, his officers and all the military who gave me the opportunity to strengthen my feeling of belonging.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, an exciting event is taking place in London, Ontario this summer which will foster the spirit of goodwill and unity in the country.
Open Homes Canada, Bienvenue Canada, is a unique, Canada-wide exchange program which was initiated in London, Ontario.
Londoners will be opening their homes to fellow Canadians for a four-day visit on the civic holiday weekend of August 1.
This exchange is an attempt to bring people together to share their homes, interests and activities and to understand each other better.
All MPs will be contacted by Open Homes Canada and challenged to try and send one visitor or family from their constituencies to London, Ontario.
Ordinary people from all walks of life have a crucial role to play in renewing Canada. Open Homes Canada is one way we as Canadians can be part of the unity process.
I encourage and challenge each of you to get involved and inform your constituents. With everyone's support and participation a renewed Canada may be only a weekend away.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Minister of Industry, Science and Technology spoke in Toronto last week with a message to Canadian business people which deserves emphasis.
The minister stated that prosperity in our country greatly hinges on increased investment levels and cited Japan as an inspiration to follow in the sense that long-term planning accomplishes a higher state of competitiveness.
Our standard of living in Canada is 25 per cent higher than that of Japan and we are second only to the United States. Therefore the benefits of increased investment by the private sector will not only maintain that standard but it will also improve upon it.
We have set an impressive record over the past 30 years by establishing the second highest economic growth rate of the G-7 nations.
These are encouraging statements made by the minister and the message is clear: Increased competitiveness is the key to future prosperity.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speakerposition: Leader of the Official Opposition
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the Minister of Finance. Yesterday in Toronto the Minister of Finance told bankers that he was very optimistic. However, since he brought down his budget the minister has revised his economic growth predictions for 1992 downward from 2.7 per cent to 2.3 per cent.
That being said, will the Minister of Finance revise his forecast for unemployment upward to reflect the impact of his economic policies?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I know the hon. member is encouraged as I am that we have had positive growth in the last three months of this year. It has been modest and moderate but, nonetheless, it is going in the right direction.
Today we have had new evidence that the economy is strengthening inasmuch as on the manufacturing side shipments are up by 0.9 per cent. Orders were up by 0.8 per cent in the month of March. That, too, is encouraging.
We have indicated all along that because of the restructuring accompanying this slowdown the job side of the picture is not as optimistic as we would like to see it.
Nonetheless, with the continuing decline in interest rates, with the strengthening of the U.S. economy, with the initiatives that have been taken in the budget, and with the improvements in productivity, it all augurs well for a stable and durable recovery.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speakerposition: Leader of the Official Opposition
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Royal Bank announced its forecast for the economy yesterday and predicted growth of only 1.4 per cent. This is very much in line with what the Conference Board predicted two weeks ago: growth of only 1 per cent.
Oral Questions
In releasing the report the bank said: "That type of growth is not enough to stop the unemployment rate from rising or lead to a substantial recovery in profits".
Why is the minister sticking to his predictions at this moment for jobs when every indicator makes it very clear that he was wrong on that forecast? Will he revise it so that the Canadian people know the real unemployment situation?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Very simply, Mr. Speaker, if the hon. member wants to quote from the observations of the Royal Bank of Canada, I will do the same thing.
Mr. Earl Sweet, the Royal Bank's assistant chief economist said in connection with the release of his projections: "On the plus side the significant restructuring by Canadian business needed to regain and increase their share of world markets is beginning to make itself felt in stronger productivity and exports to the United States are growing".
The hon. member and his party continually harp at the government's initiative to try to expand trade opportunities.
It is quite obvious it is the merchandise trade, the exports out of Canada particularly to the United States but also to other countries, that will create jobs and economic activity and is what will improve our standard of living. That is what we are pursuing on all fronts.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speakerposition: Leader of the Official Opposition
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, since we have been in a recession for virtually 30 months, it is obvious that sooner or later, something will happen. Something will suddenly happen in the Canadian economy when we have a new government in Canada.
In the meantime, we have problems which cannot be denied. Manpower temporary services says that this summer the employment situation is worse than last year. In some sectors it is the worst situation since 1978, when surveys in that field were started.
Why is the Minister of Finance being stubborn? Why does he not want to do anything concrete to give jobs to


Oral Questions
the young people who want to be employed this summer so that they can go back to university next fall?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am not being stubborn at all. What we have to do is try to get the fundamentals in place.
We set out in the budget of 1991 to bring down inflation so that we could bring interest rates down and keep them down. As of today treasury bills are trading at 5.95 per cent, one of the lowest levels in over 20 years.
That is a clear indication that if the fundamentals are right and the initiatives are in place it will spur economic activity, particularly in the manufacturing and processing sector.
If productivity is increased you are then more competitive. You can then compete for those markets abroad, not only in the United States, but also in other countries of the world. That is what my colleague, the Minister of Industry, Science and Technology, is working at.
On the training and retraining side, the Minister of Employment and Immigration has expanded the budget for training and skills upgrading.
Those are all important components of a rational, realistic approach to economic recovery. That is what we are following.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the fact is that the Minister of Employment and Immigration has not expanded the budget. In fact, last year, the minister cut $100 million for job training from the Canadian Jobs Strategy. This year he slashed another $100 million from the Canadian Jobs Strategy for training. Now he has the unmitigated audacity to admit: "We have a problem. There is no money". Is it any wonder?
Exactly what does the minister intend to do to solve the problem that he himself and his government created?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speakerposition: Minister of Employment and Immigration
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the minister intends to address the problem by looking at ways where a plan can
be developed within the UI account to provide additional funds this year for developmental uses.
If we are able to put such a plan in place, it will mean that unemployed Canadians in need of training will benefit from even more than the $400 million that we included in the last budget by another increased amount. I should be able to finalize that within the next few days.

Mr. Speaker, the minister has admitted that the UI training fund has run dry.
Under the Canadian Jobs Strategy he has admitted that his government has slashed $200 million to help unemployed Canadians reintegrate into the workforce.
I ask the minister in all sincerity if his government really wants to help the 1.5 million Canadians who are unemployed get trained, at the very least will he restore the $200 million that he cut from job training under the Canadian Jobs Strategy?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speakerposition: Minister of Employment and Immigration
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in keeping with Liberal traditions, of course the member does not say who in Canada should be taxed more to raise $200 million. Or maybe he is suggesting that we increase the deficit.
The hon. member leaves the impression that we have used training funds. If he wants to be honest with the House and the people he will admit that training funds in Canada have gone up $400 million this year for UI recipients. That is the reality.
We are in the process of finalizing a plan that will provide additional funds for developmental uses this year. In order to achieve this we will, of course, have to be reallocating funds within that envelope in order to clearly show the government priority to training.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs.
Certainly, there are many outstanding issues and difficult issues being dealt with in the Constitution now. Every Canadian is aware of that, as is everyone in this House.


I congratulate the minister and all those from the provinces who agreed to have aboriginal people at the table and to discuss aboriginal issues. All Canadians agree it is time for that long-outstanding historical issue regarding Canada's First Nations to be dealt with.
Today the minister is quoted as saying that provinces uncomfortable with the proposed constitutional agreement on aboriginal self-government could opt out of a new constitutional arrangement.
Could the minister tell this House whether or not in his view this jeopardizes the legitimacy of the tentative agreement that was reached last week on the inherent right to self-government for aboriginal peoples?

speakeroldname: Right Hon. Joe Clark (President of the Privy Council and Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs; President of the Privy Council
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I thank the leader of the New Democratic Party for her question. Let me take the opportunity to thank all members of the House for the encouragement they have given me through these negotiations.
The answer to her question is that in my judgment, it does not jeopardize the agreement. The question was raised by one of the premiers who indicated that it should not be interpreted that he would be intending to invoke that right. I think that as a matter of law he is correct, but I have no reason to believe that there will be any unravelling of the agreements that occurred on aboriginal issues.

Mr. Speaker, the fact is the matter has been raised. I am sure the minister is quite correct. We all agree he is certainly very familiar with all aspects of the Constitution. It may be that Premier Wells, who made this comment, was not necessarily suggesting that he on behalf of his province would do so, but it does raise a very important question.
I believe Canadians and indeed aboriginal people feel that any agreement reached on aboriginal issues would apply to aboriginal people and First Nations in every part of this country.
I ask the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs, on behalf of himself and his government, will he assure this House that it is his intention to support and to
Oral Questions
ensure that the final agreement will contain a clause on the inherent right of aboriginal self-government?

speakeroldname: Right Hon. Joe Clark (President of the Privy Council and Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs; President of the Privy Council
speechtext:
Let me deal with that question directly, Mr. Speaker.
Yes, it is our intention. We think that there has been historic progress made on these matters, not simply in the establishment of the inherent right, but also in the recognition by aboriginal peoples that that must be exercised within Canada, that there must be other recognitions of the sovereignty of Canada, that the right would be inherent, and most important, the agreement by all parties that there would be a three-year period before which anyone would take it to court.
That should give a great deal of comfort to everyone. It gives us three years in which we can work out by negotiation, not by court decree, not by the decision of politicians or by native leaders, but work out by negotiation the form of aboriginal self-government.
The one other thing I should say has to do with the word "agreement" coming out of the process that I am chairing. It is understood by everyone that any conclusions we come to at that table have to be approved by respective governments. So in a sense, there is no formal agreement, but there is a willingness around the table to work to secure the agreement of governments to the proposals that have been the subject of consensus there.

A supplementary question, Mr. Speaker.
I would like to ask the minister this question. In terms of the position taken by the federal government, if it is clear and if it is his intention to ensure that the recognition to the inherent right of self-government for aboriginal people, as negotiated in this round, is advocated by this government will be that it will be the right of inherent self-government for aboriginal peoples, first nations in all parts of this country. Is he prepared to commit today that this is the position he is taking on behalf of the government and that it is his intention to see this in the final package?

Oral Questions

speakeroldname: Right Hon. Joe Clark (President of the Privy Council and Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs; President of the Privy Council
speechtext:
Yes, Mr. Speaker, that is our intention. We have dealt in the discussions with the principle of the equity of access to the right. We are agreed that the right should be available to all aboriginal people.
The other thing that has been done which is of potentially historic importance, if we are able to cany it off, is that the provinces have been forthcoming with regard to undertakings to make available land and to keep in place social and other services for the Metis people in a way that would allow the Government of Canada, with those assurances, to move forward to have all aboriginal people, including the Metis, included under section 91(24).

GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the European Community has recently agreed to reform its common agricultural policy in such a way as to contribute to an early conclusion of the Uruguay round of the GATT.
Throughout these negotiations the government has assured Canadian dairy, poultry and egg producers that it will deliver a clarified and a strengthened article XI. Does it still believe that it can do that?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, that is the position of the government. We are encouraged by the movement on the part of the European Community on reform of the common agricultural policy which I would say is a necessary ingredient to a successful resolution of the export subsidies and the internal support limitations for the Uruguay round.
That does not in any way affect our position on article XI. We still have the position of strengthening and clarifying article XI. We continue to discuss this with our trade partners. We would note that other countries have specific items that they want to have dealt with in the negotiations as well. So the book is not closed on that one by any means.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in the current North American free trade negotiations, the United States has demanded that automobiles entering its market duty free must have a higher North American content.
In 1988 the government fought hard against higher North American content on the grounds that it would discourage further foreign investment and jobs in Canada.
Is that still the government's policy or is the government now agreeing to a higher North American auto content in the NAFTA negotiations?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the rule of origin is a very important part of the negotiations of the NAFTA, particularly as it affects the automotive sector. It has been a key objective of the Government of Canada in the negotiations to have a clarification, a greater transparency, a greater ease of administration and compliance to the rule of origin. We seem to be achieving that during the course of the negotiations.
The question of the level of content has not been negotiated. Some flexibility is provided as a result of the acceptance of the Canadian approach to the calculation of the rule of origin and that will enter into a final negotiated position on what that level might be.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister.
The Prime Minister yesterday in this House compared the very existence of Canadian supply management and the livelihoods of tens of thousands of Canadians to the importation of bananas into Europe. No Canadian farmer has any idea what the Prime Minister was talking about.
For months now we have been told the Prime Minister's strategy has been to get onside individual leaders, particularly President Bush.


Oral Questions
What support did the Prime Minister get from President Bush after his latest round of talks with the President? If he did not get any support, what further action is he prepared to take to get that support?

speakerposition: Prime Minister
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend surprises me with his question. First of all, the misstatement is very substantial. I made no comparison whatsoever of article XI and bananas. The Liberals got no bananas; the hon. member is bananas.
Oh, oh.

speakerposition: Speaker pro tempore
speechtext: This may take awhile, but let us start again.

speakerposition: Prime Minister
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I will not go any further. I was indicating simply that other countries seek exceptions as Canada has been doing.
If my hon. friend does not know it, the European countries which formerly had colonies are seeking a very important exception to allow for the entiy of the primary product of bananas into the European Community as an exception in much the same way as the United States of America is seeking an exception for the provisions of the Jones Act in respect of its maritime industry, and in much the same way as Canada is seeking an exception in respect of the products under article XI. That is the point I was trying to make.
That is the point I made and that is the point that President Delors of Europe acknowledged here when he said that he would rather have an agreement that was 90 per cent complete with a few exceptions than no agreement at all.
I am sorry that my hon. friend did not understand the background to this complex issue. If there is any other information he would need with regard to developments in the agricultural file, please let me know.

Mr. Speaker, the Prime Minister should know that article XI is now in GATT. There is no comparison between article XI and those two situations. Surely the Prime Minister of this country should know that.
The Prime Minister and the government have been telling us to depend on the Prime Minister's personal brand of diplomacy. Canadians have seen this diplomacy
in action and they do not like it. The Prime Minister has given away fish to France and has received no support.
He has caved in on a number of trade issues to Washington and he has received no support. In fact, the head of GATT, Arthur Dunkel says: "Thriffication with no exceptions for Canadian supply management".
What is the Prime Minister prepared to do to get this support from other countries?

speakerposition: Prime Minister
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, all I can say is that if a guy does not know about bananas he does not know about fish.
The fact of the matter is that we have given away absolutely nothing to France. Due to the efforts of the distinguished Minister of Fisheries and Oceans, the European Community has stopped overfishing off the coast of Newfoundland and Labrador and that is a tribute to the leadership of the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans.
Hear, hear.

speakerposition: Prime Minister
speechtext:
All I can do is indicate to my hon. friend that while there are no guarantees in this business, we have been working very hard with the stakeholders and with the producers to try and protect that provision of the agricultural industry which is so important to a number of Canadian producers and to the Canadian family farm in many instances.
We view it as a legitimate exemption. Other people do not share that view. Perhaps my hon. friend does not share that view because he tries to trivialize it by failing to understand that it is an exemption in much the same way as the maritime industry is an exemption for the Americans, and in much the same way for a developing country whose only export product is bananas constitutes an exemption.
The Liberals laugh at it, but for developing countries which only have that produce to secure foreign exchange, it is of vital importance that they secure an exemption in that regard.
What we are trying to do is encourage that exemption for developing countries. We accept the exemption in respect of the United States and we hope that others will view the exemption we are seeking on behalf of article XI as an appropriate instrument as well.


Oral Questions

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Employment and Immigration.
When declaring 1985 International Youth Year, the United Nations warned of the potential for explosions among unemployed and alienated youth. We have had youth disturbances now in Canada-in Toronto, Halifax and elsewhere-to which the Ontario government has responded by initiating an emergency job program for youth.
Is the minister and his government prepared to join with Ontario and other provinces in initiating an urgent program for job creation for youth this summer in order to respond to the deep concern about the potential for a long, hot summer?

speakeroldname: Hon. Pierre H. Cadieux (Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport) and Minister of State (Youth) and Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport); Minister of State (Youth); Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, obviously nobody is pleased with certain developments that have led to violence in this country and other countries around the world. I am sure nobody condones that.
With respect to this government's programs for youth, my hon. friend will admit we have had programs in place for a long time. We are very pleased that the provinces are ready now to do their part in order to help us find jobs for those students during the summer.

Mr. Speaker, Manpower Temporary Services indicates the job situation this summer will be the worst since 1982. Meanwhile, this government is spending only 70 per cent as much money now as it was in 1989 for summer youth employment.
With an unemployment rate among youth already at 17.7 per cent and going up this summer, it is more important to have action than rhetoric. Will this government act to introduce an emergency summer program for youth with the urgency it deserves before there is more trouble in this country?

speakeroldname: Hon. Pierre H. Cadieux (Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport) and Minister of State (Youth) and Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport); Minister of State (Youth); Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Canadian people agree they prefer action to rhetoric; that is why we are on this side of the House and the hon. member is on the other side.
With respect to statistics, Statistics Canada has indicated recently that students have better chances of finding employment this summer than they had last summer. Notwithstanding that, we have increased the Challenge Program this year as we did last year.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:

speakeroldname: Right Hon. Joe Clark (President of the Privy Council and Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs; President of the Privy Council
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I rise to report to the House of Commons on the Canada round, on the distance we have travelled on the road to constitutional renewal, and on the distance we must still go to succeed.
At the invitation of the Prime Minister during 19 days of meetings in seven cities across Canada, ministers and aboriginal leaders have met to find ways to move this country forward.
I believe we are closer than ever to healing the wounds that bind us, to keeping the country that unites us. The progress we have made is unprecedented.
We had set May 31 as a target to conclude, but in Toronto we agreed that we had come so far that we should continue. Our purpose is agreement on all aspects of the Canada round, and that goal is within reach. We agreed in Toronto to a pause to consult, to gain some perspective, to identify areas where compromise might occur.
We have all learned hard lessons from the past. We have realized that we cannot make Canada more inclusive unless the process to get there is inclusive as well. We have all realized that no single part of this country can move forward in isolation and that the Canada round is necessary not just in name but in substance. We have all realized that no single part of this country can move forward in isolation, that a Canada round is necessary not just in name but in substance. We have all realized that closing doors does not open minds. So we are discussing a wide range of issues today: equalization, a new Senate, a common market within Canada, a new relationship with aboriginal peoples.
Nothing is agreed yet. There will be no final agreement until there is full agreement on a full package of change. But we are on the way to real change.


Routine Proceedings
I will not review in detail every issue we have discussed, but I want to report on the major issues. Although serious questions remain to be resolved, the progress we have made is without parallel in the constitutional history of Canada. The glass is much more than half full.

First, we have reached consensus on ways to make Canadian federalism more flexible and more effective. That includes explicit recognition of exclusive provincial jurisdiction in eight areas that we believe are best handled locally-forestry, mining, tourism, housing, recreation, and municipal and urban affairs, labour market training, culture.
In the special case of culture, the Constitution would also explicitly affirm that the federal government would maintain national cultural institutions and granting programs. Any federal-provincial agreements in these areas, and in immigration, could be protected by the Constitution and thereby shielded from unilateral change.
That would also be the case for agreements respecting regional development. Powers made available to any one province would be available to all. The Constitution would constrain the federal government from using its spending power in areas of exclusive provincial jurisdiction.
If provinces want to opt out of new national shared-cost programs, they could do so, with compensation, if they undertake programs compatible with national objectives.
The Constitution would protect Canada's transfer payments from unilateral change. The commitment to national economic infrastructure and regional development to reduce disparities would be strengthened. There would be a requirement of regular consultation on equalization.

The fundamental objectives of the Canadian social and economic union would be entrenched in the Constitution. These would include social services, education, protection of the environment, the goal of full employment, of a reasonable standard of living, and a commitment to strengthen the Canadian economic union
through the free movement of persons, goods, services and capital.
There is agreement to repeal the federal power of disallowance and to limit the federal declaratory power.
Second, there is consensus on a new, more inclusive vision of the country.
We have agreed on a Canada clause that would guide the courts in interpreting the Constitution, a declaration of the fundamental features of this country, of Quebec's distinctiveness, of Canada's linguistic duality, of aboriginal rights and responsibilities, including a new third order of government, of our democratic values, of the equality of women and men, of cultures and races, of the provinces in this federation.
We are recognizing the distinct society of Quebec and ensuring that provincial governments have the means to express their identity and goals.
We have agreed to open a new partnership with the aboriginal peoples of Canada, based upon a mutual respect that involves the recognition of their inherent right to self-government within Canada. That idea is not new. The Iroquois Confederacy and other aboriginal governments practised forms of democracy here before most European countries did.
Nor should the idea cause alarm. There are forms of aboriginal self-government now in Canada and they work better than the colonial systems which have created such despondency and such despair among Canadian aboriginals. The difference is that now those governments would be rooted in the Constitution.
The right would not be contingent, nor delayed. It is agreed that all parties would choose to wait three full years before that right was taken to court. That would give everyone time to begin to agree on what self-government would mean in particular communities, and to agree on what it would not mean. This three-year period ensures that the definitions can be worked out by agreement, by negotiation, not by the courts.
Existing provincial and federal laws would continue to apply until aboriginal governments have the authority to adopt new regimes which would operate within the Canadian system but would reflect aboriginal reality. The charter of rights would apply as it does to provinces.


Existing treaty rights would be protected and interpreted in a manner that is just, broad and liberal, taking into account their spirit and intent.
There have also been undertakings by the provinces with respect to land and the maintenance and services that would allow the federal government to include all aboriginal peoples, including the Metis, in section 91(24) of the Constitution.

Third, we are well on the way to improving substantially the national and federal institutions of Canada.
The Constitution would finally entrench the composition of the Supreme Court, including three civil law judges from Quebec. The appointment of Supreme Court judges would be based on lists submitted by the provinces.
First Ministers' Conferences would be strengthened as instruments of Canadian co-operation and the Constitution would require an annual meeting of Heads of Government.
On the Senate, we have not yet settled the basic questions of the basis on which the Senate is chosen, or its powers. But a great deal is agreed. Senators would be directly elected. A system of proportional representation would be defined by Parliament to ensure that the Senate would fully reflect the diversity of Canada. The new Senate would ratify federal appointments or reject them. It would have a 30-day suspensive veto over supply bills.
There would be guaranteed representation for aboriginal Canadians. On issues of French language or culture, a double-majority rule would apply.

On all of these issues there is broad agreement on the principles and on the essence of the proposals. In many areas exact legal text has been agreed word by word, line by line.
The work of the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee has been an invaluable guide in our discussions. In many cases the specific language has been borrowed. Where we adopted a different approach, for example, in describing the jurisdiction of the provinces, I believe there was agreement among the federalist parties whose unanimity gave such authority to the report of Parliament.
Routine Proceedings
There has been extraordinary agreement. But it could all come to nothing because these discussions are not about one item and not about one agenda. This is a Canada round and we need agreement on the whole if we are to have agreement on any parts.
A question of critical importance to Canada is our ability to have the kind of common market in our country that has allowed Europe to offer such tangible benefits to its citizens. When Canada was formed trade was in goods, and the barriers to that trade were brought down by the original Confederation agreement. In that same nation-building spirit we must reduce Canada's own barriers to the free movement of people, capital, services and goods.
Two other major issues stand out: the Senate and the constitutional amending formula for changes to national institutions. I do not believe we can reach agreement on either unless we reach agreement on both. I am confident we can. But that will require flexibility and vision on the part of everyone who wants this country to continue and succeed.
Three Senate models are being considered: equal representation of provinces; equal representation of regions; and equitable representation. All models share the principle that a new Senate must be much more broadly based. All models have aspects that commend them to serious consideration by provincial and federal governments. Each model obviously presents difficulties for others.
Those who argue the absolute equality of provinces put that forward as a principle of a federation, equal in importance to the principle of representation by population. Not everyone agrees and there is equally genuine concern about a reform that would allow six provinces representing 17 per cent of the population to stop or to appreciably delay decisions of a democratically elected House of Commons.
The federal government has said that if there is a consensus in the country on a particular model we could accept that model. However, if it were to be composed on the basis of the equality of provinces its powers must be much more limited than if it were more broadly based.
We need a system that represents the different parts of Canada better but we also need a system that works, reforms that will improve government, not prevent it.


Routine Proceedings
In Toronto I put forward some views on the powers I saw as being appropriately associated with the different models under discussion. I hope this may provide some basis for agreement. So far there is no consensus on the model or the powers of a new Senate.
We must find a consensus or this whole Canada round will fail. Everyone has agreed on Senate reform. The question is whether provinces who have hard positions now are prepared to find some way to agree and to make the Canada round whole.
I believe that if we can find an acceptable model for the Senate we can find agreement on an amending formula.
Sometimes we might wish that we were a simple country: one language, one culture, one clear identity. But that is not who we are and has not been for centuries. We are a complex, accomplished society, whose success depends on our respect for ourselves and our respect for others. If that mutual respect was important in the past, it is even more essential in the modem world in which we must co-operate and compete.
These present constitutional issues are of crucial importance to Quebecers who must decide whether to stay in Canada or not. They are of crucial importance to aboriginal Canadians who have been left outside longer than anyone else. And they are for western Canadians who have felt shut out of national decisions.

We all understand that the only way to achieve our goals is to achieve them all together. But there is more to it than that. Issues which interest Quebec are of profound importance to eveiy other Canadian because if Quebec rejects Canada in October, every Canadian will suffer, materially and for generations.
Aboriginal issues are of profound importance to Quebec because if we can establish an acceptable framework for self-government that can lead to greater certainty for Quebec and more harmony in pursuit of the goals of Quebec.
Institutions which give Canadians a sense of belonging to their country strengthen the whole country. We need each other after the Constitution too, and the respect we show each other now will make it easier for us to make progress together later.
Generosity is not a luxury in Canada. It is what keeps us together as a community, just as the absence of generosity could break us into bitter pieces.
I am encouraged by the sense of generosity I have found around the constitutional table, in this House and in this country. Our real challenge now is to find the ingenuity and the generosity to make the Canada round work and to make Canada work.

Madam Speaker, I would first like to thank the minister for his statement in the House today.
On behalf of the Liberal Party of Canada and all Liberal members and senators, I can assure him that we hope for a resolution of the constitutional impasse. We support him without reservation in his efforts on behalf of the government to bring the provincial and federal governments to agree on a series of proposals that could break the constitutional deadlock.
Of course we on this side of the House are watching him with some trepidation and even impatience. It is still good to keep in mind that back in April 1991 the Leader of the Opposition and leader of the Liberal Party of Canada submitted not only a procedure for resolving the constitutional impasse but also a nine-point program that the Liberals thought would settle the constitutional issue fairly and equitably.
Hear, hear.

We are very pleased on hearing the report that the minister just gave us to see today that considerable progress has been made and that almost all of the nine suggestions made by the Liberal Party of Canada were accepted not only by the government but by all the provincial representatives who negotiated with the minister in recent weeks.
Nevertheless, I would like to draw the minister's attention to some points that we consider absolutely fundamental. I will quote what the minister himself said in his speech a few minutes ago: "The constitutional developments now under way are of the utmost importance for Quebecers. Secondly, they are also very important for native people, who have felt excluded for a very


long time, and finally for westerners who also feel left out of national decisions".
If you allow me I will return briefly to each of these three points. We Liberals believe that it is absolutely essential in this constitutional round to give Quebec back its veto on constitutional issues and amendments. That is why we proposed a constitutional amending formula that would ensure a veto for the government and people of Quebec.
We think that the minister will have failed in the discussions now going on if he is unable to convince all his provincial discussion partners of the absolute necessity of an amending formula that guarantees a veto for Quebec.
Secondly, we want to recall-

It is absolutely essential that it be fully understood, as this round cannot only be a Quebec round but ought to be a Canada round, that we do something for the aboriginal people.
I heard the minister saying here today, and I will quote him again: "We have agreed to open a new partnership with the aboriginal people of Canada based on a mutual respect that involves the recognition of their inherent right to self-government within Canada". Then he went on to say: "That idea is not new, nor should the idea cause alarm".
It is quite clear that the Liberals profoundly believe the time has come to recognize the aboriginal right of self-government within our Constitution. For us, there is no alarm. We are very concerned when on the one hand we see the minister speaking and being very open and generous in order to achieve this and on the other hand we see his colleague, the minister of health, on TV making all kinds of difficulties or so-called difficulties about this very simple fact that ought to be part of this current negotiation round.
We are hopeful that every Canadian from every political party and every level of government will be generous enough to understand and accept the wording that has been put in the Beaudoin-Dobbie reports in relation to aboriginal issues.
Finally, the third component of what we think is essential as part of the Canada round is a tangible progress in reforming the Senate in a way that would be
Routine Proceedings
satisfactory to the legitimate aspirations of westerners and people of less populated provinces, who think that the overwhelming representation of Ontario and Quebec in the House of Commons makes them a smaller part of the decision process in Ottawa.
We Liberals believe that there ought to be a reform of the Senate that will allow a better representation, if not in the House of Commons then certainly in the Senate, in order to meet these legitimate aspirations of these provinces.
I want to be quite clear that the Liberal Party, under its leader, has made a series of suggestions regarding the Senate. We made these suggestions thinking that the west and the Atlantic provinces would be well served by this. In the Beaudoin-Dobbie report we dissent in relation to the Senate because we felt that the level of representation could be improved on what was suggested by the government and more particularly we felt that if we are talking of an elected Senate and a more equitable Senate, it ought to be an effective Senate also.
We felt that the proposal of the government was not going far enough in the directions of an effective Senate. Frankly, we are not afraid that the House of Commons would be paralyzed because there would be a more effective Senate.
We believe that if there is a certain price to pay in order to meet the legitimate aspirations of westerners and Atlantic Canadians it ought to be paid.
We are saying that the minister ought to work diligently to convince the representative of the provinces who are meeting with him that they have to give a veto to Quebec on the amending formula. He has also to convince his counterpart to respond in a positive fashion to a reformed Senate which seems to be needed and desired by the Atlantic provinces and the western provinces.

Finally, for everyone to win in this constitutional round we think it is essential for the Government of Canada to clarify its spending power and a new, more efficient, and functional distribution of powers to the federal and provincial governments and also to strengthen the federal government's position in the economic field.


Routine Proceedings
While we want this constitutional round to please Atlantic Canadians, Quebecers, Ontarians, and westerners, there must also be something for those who believe in a strong and effective central government for Canada. We think that depends on strengthening section 121 of the Constitution.
We were pleased with what the minister said about this desire to ensure greater freedom for the movement of goods, people, services and capital in Canada and we want to tell him that we support this effort to ensure that Canada is really a common market and that the Liberal Party of Canada will always fully support his efforts to convince the provincial representatives to accept constitutional changes to strengthen Canada's economic union.
In closing, Madam Speaker, I would like to remind the minister that he is entering the crucial phase of negotiations, as he himself knows. Obviously, unanimity would be the best outcome. Of course a unanimous position of the federal government and all the provinces on a set of proposals would be the best of all worlds, but it certainly will not be easy to achieve or even possible.
I would like to quote an article that appeared on May 30 in La Presse. Journalist Marcel Adam wrote that Meech failed because of the unanimity requirement:
That is why Brian Mulroney promised in February to come up with a plan that all provinces would support.
"I do not want nine tenths of an agreement," he emphasized. "I do not want two thirds of an agreement; I want all provinces to sign-"
That is what the Prime Minister of Canada said.
Mr. Adam continued:
Believe me, that statement was heard by all the premiers, who will make a point of reminding him of it when the time comes.
Mr. Adam concluded his article by saying:
If my analysis is correct, the present process will fail for the same reason as Meech: the sacrosanct principle of unanimity.
I think it is very important that we understand why the leader of the Liberal Party of Canada suggested quite a while ago that we had a national referendum to make sure we are not dragged down by provincial Premiers who in their talks and discussions with the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs and the Prime Minister of Canada will always try to get more. They will
want this or object to that on the basis that it might not be popular in their province.
But at the present time the Canadian interest is paramount. If we can satisfy the legitimate demands of Quebec, the demands of native peoples, and the demands regarding an effective, equitable and elected Senate, I say to the Minister: "In the end, if you are unable to get unanimity, trust the population of Canada, organize your referendum and you will win it".
Hear, hear.

It seems certain to us that we can get a majority in the four main regions of the country in favour of a constitutional reform which serves the best interest of Canada as a whole.
We say to the minister: "Good luck. You are entering the final phase of the negotiations; you must succeed. We are behind you, but beware, nothing must be perceived as a gain for some at the expense of others". In this constitutional round, all Canadians, no matter where they live, must be winners.
We believe that if you have a set of proposals which has the support of a majority of premiers, most of the population, including that of Quebec, will vote in a referendum in favour of a renewed Canada, a Canada which would say yes to Quebec and which will let Quebecers say yes to Canada.
Hear, hear.

Madam Speaker, first of all I welcome the minister back to the House. I congratulate him on both his endurance and his patience throughout this process. He has been working very hard at it and I think we owe him a debt of gratitude for the work he has put into this particular issue.
Hear, hear.

The most important thing as we continue into the final phases of the Canada round is keeping this country united and getting Canadians marching in the same direction once again.
I am pleased from what I have found out about the negotiations to note the state of play to date in terms of what is being tentatively agreed upon. As the minister said there is no agreement until the final negotiations are completed, but the state of play to date reflects a


great deal of what we agreed in this House on the Beaudoin-Dobbie report.
I am very pleased with that because as the minister said to have an inclusive Canada round we must have an inclusive process. Let us turn to what the three parties did in terms of the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee. We had public hearings. We had six national conferences. We involved Canadians in these mini-constituent assemblies across this country. We had long and hard negotiations between the parties. We put aside our political labels. We stood up for Canada and came up with a report that is reflective of what the Canadian people want.
I say today that I am pleased to see that the provinces in the main are listening very carefully to what the Canadian people had to say. I hope later on when the premiers become involved that they too will keep an eye on public opinion and an eye on what the three parties said in the Beaudoin-Dobbie report. I think it is very important.
To date we see in the discussions held across the country some positive news for the aboriginal people of this country. We see an agreement now by all the provinces participating, plus the aboriginal people in the territories, and the federal government, to recognize the inherent right to self-government of aboriginal people. This is long overdue. It is finally going to happen. It is about time in terms of doing justice to our aboriginal people.

As regards the province of Quebec, I think that people everywhere in the country feel that Quebec is different, that it is not at all a province like the others. It is truly a unique and distinct society. Now there is agreement, and that includes Mr. Clyde Wells from Newfoundland, to enshrine the distinct society clause in the Canadian Constitution. There is also a consensus across the country to reform the Supreme Court of Canada in order to amend the Canadian Constitution and allow three civil law judges from Quebec, as well as six common law judges.
It is important for Quebec to protect its unique society, to protect a province which is different and which
Routine Proceedings
constitutes a minority not only in Canada but also in North America.

There has been progressive movement in terms of regional fairness, in terms of regional development and in terms of protecting transfer payments to the provinces from being unilaterally ended by the federal government in the future. There has been progress made in terms of strengthening section 36 of the Constitution, the section on equalization that is so important to six or seven of the provinces including my home province of Saskatchewan.
In terms of the new idea of a social covenant or of an economic union, I am pleased the governments have agreed with a report we made in this House on the details of what should go into a social covenant: the protection of medical care, higher education, primary education, the environment, the right of workers to collective bargaining, and the importance of things like full employment in Canada, decent housing, and a decent standard of living for all Canadians regardless of where they live in this country.
It is the same in terms of minorities and openness: to have some positive changes for minorities, visible and other minorities in Canada-

-and also a change in the Canadian Constitution for linguistic minorities, French speaking and English speaking ones across Canada.

Then we have the Senate. We in the committee probably wrestled more with the Senate issue than any other. I am not surprised the minister is having problems with the Senate issue when he meets with his counterparts across the country.
This is indeed the most important issue, next to perhaps the division of powers, but certainly a very difficult issue to settle in terms of trying to get a compromise and a consensus in the country.
Substantive progress has been made. We now have, for example, agreement all around to have an elected Senate, progress after over a hundred years. We have a very important agreement to have the Senate elected by proportional representation, something that I would not have predicted six or seven months ago would be agreed


Routine Proceedings
to by not only the three national political parties but all the provinces, the aboriginal people and the territories.
With proportional representation we can have a Senate where we can achieve the important goals and objectives of gender parity and representation of minorities, a House that reflects the diversity of this country more than we have today in the House of Commons or indeed in the appointed Senate. Very important progress has been made on the Senate issue.
For the aboriginal people we have agreement now to have aboriginal representation in the Senate. Even three months ago we did not have that agreement. The three parties said in our report that we would recommend aboriginal representation in the Senate if the aboriginal people agreed. At that time there was no consensus in their community. Now there must be a consensus because the aboriginal people have agreed that they should have aboriginal representation in the Senate, again veiy good progress. There has also been some progress in terms of Senate powers. Again I think it is very important.
Finally, in terms of the substantive matters we have on the table to settle the whole issue of whether or not the Senate should be equal or the Senate should be equitable. Tied into that is the amending formula in terms of how we should reform the Constitution in the future.
In terms of the amending formula we have a couple of new ideas on the table. One was proposed by Saskatchewan which would give Quebec and Ontario, the big provinces, and a combination of smaller provinces a veto namely seven provinces representing 85 per cent of the population. This is something we did not have that is worth considering.
We have another idea that is new for the Northwest Territories. Again it is worth considering in terms of the amending formula.
The important matter that will have to be resolved- and this is why I am glad there is a pause this week where people can go back and reflect-is whether the Senate should be equal or equitable.
In the House we have given some pretty clear directions to the minister that we believe the model should be one of greater equity between the provinces.
We have notionally the idea that we have five regions in the country, each with around 20 per cent of the
senators. That would give the small provinces a lot more representation and a lot more clout compared to what they have now. That is the important issue. When we talk about whether it is equitable or equal in the Senate it leads directly to the powers of the Senate. Those two things have to be worked out over the few weeks that lie ahead.
There are one or two other things I want to say. I would like to say to Robert Bourassa, the premier of Quebec, that the rest of Canada has shown its good will. The rest of Canada has gone a considerable distance. The rest of Canada has made some very substantive progress. The time has come very soon when the premier of Quebec should come back to the bargaining table and have some input on behalf of the people of his province.

Madam Speaker, I know that it was difficult following the failure of Meech Lake. However, I also think that the rest of the country is now acting in good faith. We feel that we have the necessary flexibility to make arrangements, not only for Quebecers but also for the aboriginal peoples, the rest of the country, the smaller provinces, and everybody because this is truly a Canada Round.
Given this good faith, it is time for Mr. Bourassa to act. It is time to go back to the negotiation table to represent the population of Quebec. Now is the time to act.

In conclusion, we have a great country. Canadian people are now saying to those of us who are politicians that the time has come to negotiate the deal. The time has come to make the accommodation. The time has come to make the arrangement and to settle the constitutional issue in the next few weeks and put this issue behind us so that in a few months' time we can get back to dealing with the real issues which are issues of hunger, employment, jobs and the recession, real issues that real people face.
